Title:
First record of the brown-rot fungus Phaeolus schweinitzii
from Pakistan identified by Morphological and Molecular methods
Abstract:
Phaeolus schweinitzii is a cosmopolitan brown rot fungus
important in pharmaceutical, biotechnological and food products. In the
present study, Phaeolus schweinitzii collection is for the first time
from Khanaspur and Changa Manga forest of Pakistan. This species was
characterized based on both morphological and molecular characters.
Under morphological characterization, both macroscopic and microscopic
features were investigated. On the other hand, molecular classification
is based on the amplification of the nuclear ribosomal DNA (rDNA)
internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions. Specimens of the P.
schweinitzii were found on living trees of Conifer sp., which is
characterized by sessile basidiomata and ellipsoid to oval-shaped
basidiospores. The basidiocarp is characterized by its non-laccate brown
pileal surface with a yellowish-brown margin. The phylogenetic analysis
found the sequences from this study to form a monophyletic strongly
supported clade with other Phaeolus schweinitzii sequences downloaded
from the GeneBank with 100 bootstrap and 1.0 posterior probability. The
findings of this study have contributed to the biodiversity information
and provide important information about the presence of the plant
pathogenic fungus which causes detrimental effects to the forests.
